title: Powell should reflect on his responsibility for US foreign policy being in shambles
text:
A lot of people don’t like President Trump, and some of them are part of the reason he was elected in the first place. Take Colin Powell, for example.

Last Sunday the former secretary of state told CNN that U.S. foreign policy is “in shambles right now, in my humble judgment.”

To quote Winston Churchill, he has much to be humble about.

As secretary of state in 2003, Powell was in a position to prevent what turned out to be one of the worst foreign policy disasters in U.S. history, the invasion of Iraq over Saddam Hussein’s alleged stockpiles of weapons of mass destruction.

Instead, he pushed aside any doubts and gave a speech at the United Nations to urge the world to war.

“The facts and Iraq’s behavior show that Saddam Hussein and his regime are concealing their efforts to produce more weapons of mass destruction,” Powell told the U.N. on February 5, 2003.

Powell showed “evidence” of “chemical bunkers” and spoke of a “thick intelligence file” with information about “biological weapons factories on wheels and on rails.”

“The gravity of this moment is matched by the gravity of the threat that Iraq’s weapons of mass destruction pose to the world,” Powell said.

Over and over, Powell described Iraq’s “behavior” as it supposedly tried to deceive U.N. inspectors into believing it had no weapons of mass destruction.

And then, as we all know, the U.S. found no weapons of mass destruction.

The invasion of Iraq began just over a month after Powell’s U.N. speech and the major combat operations lasted about five weeks. Then the reckoning began. In June, Newsweek reported that when military planners at Central Command were planning the invasion, they had “tried to get a fix from the CIA on WMD sites they could take out with bombs and missiles.”

Eventually, “after much badgering,” the CIA let the CENTCOM planners see the intelligence on WMD sites. “It was crap,” a CENTCOM planner told the magazine. The sites were mostly old buildings the U.S. had bombed in 1991, another source said.

During the 1991 Gulf War, Colin Powell was in charge of the Army Forces Command and was chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Is it plausible that he didn’t recognize what the CENTCOM planners recognized?

CalChamber files sensible challenge to acrylamide signs In 2003, Powell was likely the one person in the Bush administration with the knowledge and credibility to stand up to those who were rushing to war, a war that has been endless for the United States.

Yet, when his judgment mattered and the fate of millions of people and trillions of dollars were on the line, he helped lay the foundation for a chaotic foreign policy inherited by Donald Trump.

While it may be easy to forget, history didn’t just begin with Trump’s election.

Donald Trump campaigned on ending endless wars, and if the country hadn’t agreed with him, Jeb Bush or Hillary Clinton (who voted for the war) might be president today.

While President Trump has yet to actually back up his rhetoric against America’s perpetual wars, Colin Powell and other Trump critics who advocated for the war in Iraq have no ground to stand on.
